conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (E or F) liquid will flow into after passing through baffles.
The liquid flows from four nozzles labeled A, B, C, and D at the top of the setup.
The containers at the bottom are labeled E (left-hand side) and F (right-hand side).
Stream A hits the grey baffle and is deflected to the right.
Streams B and C strike the yellow slanted barrier, merge, and are deflected to the left together.
Stream D strikes the blue slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
Stream A hits the yellow baffle and is deflected to the left.
Streams A, B, and C merge and encounter the red baffle, where they are deflected to the left together.
Stream D flows along the blue slanted barrier without changing its direction.

premise: Stream A is deflected to the right by the grey baffle, then to the left by the yellow baffle, and merges with Streams B and C, which are deflected to the left by the yellow barrier and red baffle.
conclusion: Streams A, B, and C ultimately flow toward container F.

premise: Stream D is deflected to the left by the blue slanted barrier and flows along it without further deflections.
conclusion: Stream D ultimately flows toward container E.

premise: Streams A, B, and C merge and are deflected to the left by the red baffle, while Stream D flows along the blue slanted barrier.
conclusion: Most liquid from A, B, and C and little liquid from D end in container F, with most liquid from D reaching container E.
